718844f-a.title: Manhattan: Chrystie Street - Stanton Street
718844f-a.text:
No. 1
Chrvstie Street, east side, north from but not including Stanton Street.
July 18, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.
No. 2
A similar view. Note the surface car tracks. The buildings shown at the left will shortly be demolished and their sites included in the playground area named for the Presidents mother, Sarah Delano Roosevelt. This extends from Canal to Houston Streets, with a width
of one city block; Chrystie to Forsyth Streets.
July i928.
George L. Balgue
May be reproduced.
718844f-a.folder: Chrystie Street & Stanton Street, Manhattan, NY

718846f-a.title: Manhattan: Chrystie Street - Stanton Street
718846f-a.text:
221-225 Chrvstie Street, west side, between Stanton and East
Houston Streets.
July 23, 1930.
P. L. Sperr.
718846f-a.folder: Chrystie Street & Stanton Street, Manhattan, NY

718845f-b.title: Manhattan: Chrystie Street - Stanton Street
718845f-b.text:
(1)
Chrvstie Street, west side, north from between Stanton and Nast Houston Streets. (Second Ave, is a continuation of Chrystie Street, from East Houston Street northward.) The clearance in the forearound is the site for Roosevelt Park. The view also howa East Houston Street, north side, east from and including Chrystie Btreet, to but not including
Forsyth Street.
June 25, 1934.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
Tho same, at an earlier date, from a point slightly southward.
March 13, 1934.
P. L. Sperr.
718845f-b.folder: Chrystie Street & Stanton Street, Manhattan, NY
